body: this probably only happens when the file with pid exists but the process itself is already dead.
i have same issue at every cap deploy...

my workaround is run cap deploy:start before cap deploy :)
a little bit weird but works... lol

I have a similar issue. sidekiq seems to shut down uncleanly after :quiet leaving the pid around, so doing a :stop fails (i.e. the pid is there but the proc isn't). I solved it by adding a task to delete that pid before :stop is called. not the cleanest, but it works…

Every time I 'fix' capistrano for one person, it breaks for another person.
 So I'm going to be extra hesitant to change anything unless someone can
document exactly how Sidekiq's current recipe is wrong.  I'm not saying
it's perfect as is, but I need evidence.

On Thu, Jan 24, 2013 at 8:38 AM, Oren Mazor notifications@github.comwrote:

> I have a similar issue. sidekiq seems to shut down uncleanly after :quiet
> leaving the pid around, so doing a :stop fails (i.e. the pid is there but
> the proc isn't). I solved it by adding a task to delete that pid before
> :stop is called. not the cleanest, but it works…
> 
> —
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHubhttps://github.com/mperham/sidekiq/issues/637#issuecomment-12659956.

@mperham the only real problem is that if the sidekiq process is down, the `stop` task(and therefore the `restart` task as well) fails. to solve this, the only thing to change is: if the `stop` task detects that sidekiq's pid isnt "up" anymore, it just show a warning/message like "process with pid 123 doesn't exist" instead of failing. That way, capistrano will continue to the `start` task and the deploy will work.
@plentz I'd love a PR to do just that.  Hard for me to do it since I can't reproduce.

issue.title: Fixes Issue #637 "cap sidekiq:stop fails if it's already stoped"

repository.name: sidekiq
repository.description: Simple, efficient background processing for Ruby

issue.body: Adds ":on_error => :continue" setting to the stop and quiet tasks in the capistrano recipe. Now instead of failing the tasks show the error message and continue, when sidekiq is already stopped. fixes #637

body: Sorry for the duplication...I was a bit confused. ;)

issue.title: making capistrano's stop/quiet tasks don't fail if sidekiq is already stopped

repository.name: sidekiq
repository.description: Simple, efficient background processing for Ruby

body: just saw @sfroehler patch and I really don't know what's the best approach. His code is a lot cleaner and short, but mine don't show a ugly error message and just say that sidekiq is not running. @mperham is your turn :)
(or maybe just call the troops to take a look and help you to decide - both will solve the problem anyway)
@plentz I prefer your approach at first glance.  Will investigate more tonight.

I don't really like this long lines with a lot of bash stuff in it - I think they are hard to read/understand. But thats just a personal opinion. If it's just about the content of the error message: It can be amended in the sidekiqctl. I prefer the "Process doesn't exists" because thats the actual "problem". I would want to know that, so I can investigate what went wrong.
At the end @plentz is right - both patches will fix the issue and that's what we all want. ;)

issue.title: Should not fail the deployment if sidekiq is stopped.
issue.body:
If sidekiq is already stopped but the pid file exists, it should continue
the deployment. See https://github.com/mperham/sidekiq/issues/637
